front: Explain how a bubble sort can sort a list.
back:
• Compare the first two items in the list.
  • If they are in the wrong order then swap them.
  • Move to the next pair of items.
  • Repeat until the end of the list is reached, this will be the first pass.
  • Make a second pass through the list for one less iteration, as the last item is now in order.
  • Once a pass is made with no swaps, the list is sorted.

front: Explain how a breadth-first traversal is used to traverse a graph.
back:
• From start node, add all neighbours to a visited queue, and mark start node as discovered.
  • Dequeue neighbour queue, mark that node as discovered, and add its unvisited/undiscovered neighbours to the queue.
  • Effectively, traverse all of the children of one node before going down to their children.
  • Continue until the queue becomes empty, at which point graph is fully traversed.

front:
What is breadth-first search (BFS)?
What is it typically used for?
back:
• BFS explores all neighbours of a node before moving to the next level (layer-by-layer).
  • It uses a queue (FIFO) data structure.
  • Applications: finding the shortest path in an unweighted graph, peer-to-peer networks, GPS navigation (unweighted maps).

front:
What is depth-first search (DFS)?
What is it typically used for?
back:
• DFS explores as far as possible down one branch before backtracking.
  • It uses a stack (explicit or via recursion).
  • Applications: maze solving, topological sorting, cycle detection, scheduling problems.

front:
Compare breadth-first search (BFS) and depth-first search (DFS).
Which is more suitable for shortest path finding?
back:
• BFS guarantees shortest path in an unweighted graph, DFS does not.
  • BFS uses a queue → requires more memory, but ensures optimal path.
  • DFS uses a stack/recursion → less memory in sparse graphs, but may get "lost" in deep branches.
  • Exam tip: AQA often asks why BFS is better for shortest path questions → because it visits nodes in increasing distance order.

front:
What are the three tree traversal methods?
Give one use for each.
back:
• Pre-order: Root → Left → Right. Used for copying/cloning trees.
  • In-order: Left → Root → Right. Used for binary search trees (BSTs) → outputs nodes in ascending order.
  • Post-order: Left → Right → Root. Used for deleting/freeing trees, and converting infix to postfix (RPN).

front: In a binary search tree, which traversal would give values in ascending order? Why?
back: In-order traversal gives ascending order.Because it visits left subtree (smaller values), then root, then right subtree (larger values), maintaining BST ordering.

front:
What is binary search?
What condition must hold for binary search to work?
back:
• Binary search repeatedly halves the search interval until the target is found.
  • Requires the list to be sorted.
  • Time complexity: O(log n).

front:
Compare binary search and binary tree search.
When might binary tree search be less efficient than binary search?
back:
• Both aim for O(log n) average complexity.
  • Binary search works on arrays/lists; binary tree search works on binary search trees (BSTs).
  • If a BST is unbalanced (like a linked list), time complexity degrades to O(n).

front:
What is the time complexity of bubble sort?
Why is bubble sort considered inefficient?
back:
• Worst and average case: O(n²).
  • Compares and swaps adjacent elements repeatedly until sorted.
  • Inefficient: large number of comparisons/swaps compared to divide-and-conquer methods.

front:
Describe merge sort.
What is its time complexity?
back:
• Merge sort is a divide and conquer algorithm: splits list into halves, recursively sorts, then merges.
  • Time complexity: O(n log n) in best, worst, and average cases.
  • Efficient and stable, but requires extra memory for merging.

front:
Compare bubble sort and merge sort.
Which is more suitable for large datasets? Why?
back:
• Bubble sort: O(n²) → impractical for large n.
  • Merge sort: O(n log n) consistently.
  • Merge sort is far more efficient for large datasets, but bubble sort may be used in teaching or very small datasets due to simplicity.

front:
What is Dijkstra’s shortest path algorithm used for?
What are some real-world applications?
back:
• Dijkstra finds the shortest path from a starting node to all other nodes in a weighted graph (non-negative weights).
  • Applications: GPS navigation, network routing (e.g. OSPF protocol), task scheduling.
  • Exam tip: You don’t need to memorise the full steps, but must be able to trace an example.

front:
Compare Dijkstra’s algorithm and BFS.
When would you use one over the other?
back:
• BFS finds shortest path in an unweighted graph.
  • Dijkstra handles weighted graphs (positive weights).
  • If all edges have equal weight → BFS is more efficient. If weights differ → must use Dijkstra.

front:
In terms of algorithmic complexity, which is more efficient:
  1. Binary Search
  2. Linear Search
  3. Merge Sort
  4. Bubble Sort
back:
• Binary search: O(log n) → efficient for searching sorted data.
  • Linear search: O(n) → inefficient for large datasets.
  • Merge sort: O(n log n) → efficient sorting.
  • Bubble sort: O(n²) → inefficient sorting.
  • Ranking (best to worst for large n): Binary search → Merge sort → Linear search → Bubble sort.

front:
What is meant by "Divide and Conquer"?
Which algorithms in this section use it?
back:
• Divide and Conquer = breaking a problem into smaller subproblems, solving them, then combining results.
  • Merge sort is the classic example.
  • Binary search also uses Divide and Conquer (halving the list each step).

front: front
back: back

front: What is the fast way to traverse a tree by hand?
back: Draw a dot on each node, left = pre-order, bottom = in-order, right = post-order. Then draw a line anti-clockwise around the tree. The order that this line hits the dots is the traversal order.

front: What is a data structure?
back: A data structure is a way to store, organise and manage data in a way that makes it easier and more efficient to process for a program.

front: What is a root node?
back: The only node in a rooted tree which has no parent.

front: What is a hash table?
back: A hash table is a data structure that stores items at positions calculated by a hashing algorithm. The algorithm can be reapplied to a key to retrieve the stored data.

front: What is a binary tree?
back: A rooted tree where each node has, at most, two children.

front: When would an adjacency list be used over an adjacency matrix?
back: An adjacency list uses much less memory than a matrix for sparse graphs, as the lack of an edge is simply not stored. They are also much faster at adding new nodes. Adjacency lists are good when the graph is large, sparse, or needs to be updated frequently.

front: What are the types of binary tree traversals?
back:
• Pre order traversal: self -> left -> right
  • In order traversal: left -> self -> right
  • Post order traversal: left -> right -> self

front: How can a tree be implemented?
back: As a tree is a subset of graphs, it can be implemented using an adjacency list or adjacency matrix. Alternatively, it can be stored as a list/array of data, left index and right index.

front: What is a priority queue?
back: A priority queue will have a value attached to each item in the queue. The item with the lowest number (highest priority) will be dequeued first.

front: What is the difference between a static and a dynamic data structure?
back: A static data structure has a predetermined size, and cannot grow in size if more data arrives. However, a dynamic data structure can grow and shrink as needed, as it dynamically allocates memory.

front: What is a dictionary?
back: An abstract data type that stores an unordered set of key–value pairs. Values are stored and retrieved by key, not by position.

front: What is a graph?
back: A non-linear data structure that comprises a set of connected nodes.

front: What are the advantages and disadvantages of dynamic data structures?
back:
Advantages:
  • Efficient memory usage, only as much as really needed
  • Can adapt to size changes / can grow
Disadvantages:
  • Potentially slower access for some structures like linked lists.
  • More complex, requires careful memory management
  • More overhead, may require extra pointers to be stored etc.

front: What is the heap?
back: A pool of memory that is allocated to service dynamic data structures

front: What is Dijkstra's algorithm?
back: It is an algorithm to discover the shortest path between two nodes in a graph. It can be used in areas such as satellite navigation, routers etc.

front: What is a rooted tree?
back: A tree in which one node has been designated as the root.

front: What is the difference between an array and a list?
back: An array has a fixed size, and each element must be of the same data type. They are a contiguous block of memory, making them fast to access. A list is a more abstract way of storing sequential data - it can store multiple types and grow in size. If implemented as a linked list, it can be slower to access.

front: What are the advantages and disadvantages of static data structures?
back:
Advantages:
  • Potentially faster access to data compared to some dynamic structures
  • Easier to program / implement
  • Predictable memory access, only one allocation
Disadvantages:
  • The amount of space needed must be already known
  • High possibility of wasting memory
  • Difficult to resize if becomes full

front: In which scenarios would an adjacency matrix be used over an adjacency list?
back: Adjacency matrices are more efficient when the presence of an edge needs to be checked frequently. They become much more optimal when the graph is dense (each node has a lot of edges), or speed is very important.

front: What is a tree?
back: A connected, undirected graph with no cycles.

front: Where are trees used in computer science?
back:
• Binary expression trees to represent mathematical / boolean expressions.
  • In compilers to build syntax trees
  • Binary search trees to speed up searching

front: What are the two types of graph traversal? What is the same and what is different about them?
back: The two types of graph traversals are breadth-first and depth-first. Both work in a similar way - nodes can be either unvisited, visited or discovered. As you go, add unvisited nodes to a visited storage. Then go back through each visited node in storage, mark discovered, and add visit unvisited neighbours at that node. The difference is that breadth first uses a queue, while depth-first uses a stack.

front: What is the difference between a linear queue and a circular queue?
back: Both queues will have a enqueue and dequeue pointer, which are incremented when pushing and popping respectively. However, a linear queue becomes full when the enqueue pointer reaches the end of the list. A circular queue can wrap the enqueue pointer around to the front of the list to reuse memory if there has been a dequeue that has freed up space.
